messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: "swashtika" Mon / Buddhist symbol in Kodogu
messages.msgSnippet: Hi guys, those odd shaped Hitsu were also prevalent in the early Owari works and I think that this could also fit into that school as well as the Kyo and
messages.messageBody:
Hi guys, those odd shaped Hitsu were also prevalent in the early Owari
works and I think that this could also fit into that school as well as
the Kyo and Shoami as Pete mentioned. I think though that if this was
Owari or Kyo, it would be early Edo as opposed to Muromachi, though as
Pete also notes, with out the guard in hand, it is very hard to say.

Cheers

Rich



On 31/12/2005, at 4:12 AM, klepet33319 wrote:

> I would say it looks to fit into the Kyosukashi school. I was looking
> at it yesterday and it seems to be a nice piece. The small kogaibitsu
> would point toward an earlier piece. However, I suppose it could be an
> 1800's Bakamatsu period piece. I don't have it in hand nor the
> experience with metal types to make a qualified decision. In any case
> the price seems reasonable.

messages.subject: Re: "swashtika" Mon / Buddhist symbol in Kodogu
messages.msgSnippet: I would say it looks to fit into the Kyosukashi school.  I was looking at it yesterday and it seems to be a nice piece.  The small kogaibitsu would point
messages.messageBody:
I would say it looks to fit into the Kyosukashi school. I was looking
at it yesterday and it seems to be a nice piece. The small kogaibitsu
would point toward an earlier piece. However, I suppose it could be an
1800's Bakamatsu period piece. I don't have it in hand nor the
experience with metal types to make a qualified decision. In any case
the price seems reasonable.

messages.subject: "swashtika" Mon / Buddhist symbol in Kodogu
messages.msgSnippet: Listers and Lurkers, A while back a newbie posted a question about Swashtika mon tsuba and whether his wife s purchase for him was a hong kong crapper. He
messages.messageBody:
Listers and Lurkers,

A while back a newbie posted a question about
'Swashtika' mon tsuba and whether his wife's purchase
for him was a hong kong crapper. He couldn't provide a
photo, so we couldn't confirm- though evidence pointed
towards it. Several of us had seen this design used in
brass hong kongers recently.

Just revisiting the topic openly, -becuase I can't
find the newbie's email-, here are 2 things that
popped up and seem to me quite legit.

Tsuba from Benson (dead ringer for the design newbie
drew)
http://www.bushidojapaneseswords.com/4montsuba.htm

It has happened that modern kodogu slips through
Benson (I speak from personal experience, I doubt Bob
knew and the items were very good. They are the only
moderns I own.). This tsuba looks legit to me, and
most of what he sells is very good to excellent.
Anyone care to deconstruct this tsuba as not legit?

Then this popped up on Aoi today:
("Jyuyo" tachi koshirae under the Sale section)
-swashtika- mon on the kojiri.

Both are good examples of this. Its a belated
follow-up. Newbie-gent, you still out there and have a
photo of your tsuba to compare to Benson's?

Curran
